Award.AwardTitle: Tuning Oxocarbenium Ion and Acyl Iminium Ion Reactivity and Stereoelectronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Robert J. Hinkle of the College of William & Mary will explore the stereochemical preferences for attack of highly-reactive nucleophiles on cyclic oxocarbenium ions. Although formation of C-glycosides via oxocarbenium ions has been utilized in a number of total syntheses, the factors governing facial selectivity are not clear and significant erosion of selectivity occurs with highly-reactive enol ether and ketene silyl acetal nucleophiles. Studies on electronically biased, fully-substituted oxocarbenium carbon atoms will be undertaken to determine if the reactions are occurring via SN1-like, or SN2-like mechanisms. The broader impacts primarily involve training students while broadening participation through the inclusion of numerous undergraduate and Master's researchers on the project. The activities herein will continue to foster a strong, inclusive, predominantly undergraduate program at the College of William & Mary.

Establishing the factors which govern facial selectivity in the approach of nucleophiles on cyclic oxocarbenium ions could lead to greater, and more predictable, stereocontrol in the synthesis of valuable C-glycosides. These ring structures are common elements in a vast number of compounds possessing anti-cancer, antibiotic and other biological activities. The skills developed in this research will be applicable to a wide variety of chemical endeavors such as those relating to the pharmaceutical and agricultural industries as well as research to improve catalysts and develop biological probes; all of these activities require the controlled syntheses of organic molecules. Finally, this project will provide excellent mechanistic and synthetic training for undergraduate and Master's students, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the physical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This generous NSF grant supported chemical research with undergraduate and Master’s students at The College of William & Mary to provide a greater understanding of how two different sets of compounds react to afford two different types of cyclic, oxygen-containing chemical structures: (a) six-membered molecules called tetrahydropyrans (THPs); and (b) novel, tricyclic molecules called benzo[f]isochromenes (BiC). Members of both classes of compounds have shown modest activity in biological screens and tetrahydropyran ring systems in particular are ubiquitous in naturally-occurring compounds with anti-cancer and anti-fungal activities. The BiC molecules are also highly fluorescent.

Optimizing and developing the chemical reaction sequences, however, has been very challenging due to the length of the synthetic sequence (5 steps) needed to make the starting materials for the THP studies and since both series of product molecules involve in-situ generation of reactive intermediate species called oxocarbenium ions. These ions are formed via intramolecular (THP series of molecules) as well as intermolecular (BiC series) reactions of oxygen atoms with activated aldehyde and ketone functional groups.

For the THPs, an exogenous reagent (pi-nucleophile) generally traps the ion to create a new carbon-carbon bond, but this trapping could occur from one of two faces of the cyclic oxocarbenium ions to generate compounds in which the new bond is on the opposite face of the molecule (trans-), or on the same face of the molecule (cis-) as a carbon-carbon bond that is already present in the starting material. In THP-forming substrates with electron-donating groups on the reactive carbon, attack from one of the two faces predominated (trans-). Understanding and predicting the outcome of such reactions is important in organic synthesis since the different versions of THP rings (both cis- vs. trans-) appear in many biologically-active compounds. For reactions involving strong pi-nucleophiles, complex reaction mixtures were produced and separation of all of the components was not always possible. Despite what might be perceived as a failure involving these highly-reactive nucleophiles, the results add significantly to the body of knowledge for making THPs; it is crucial to know what does not work as well as what does. The studies performed ultimately resulted in more than twenty THP molecules, ten of which were submitted for biological testing.

The benzo[f]isochromene (BiC) series of molecules has been made using a very short synthetic sequence and a complex series of reactions that must occur in a specific order – a so-called domino, or cascade sequence. These types of reaction protocols have become much more common since they increase molecular complexity very rapidly and produce far less chemical waste. The entire series of separate reactions is initiated by a Lewis acid activator, but the key, second reaction (alkynyl-Prins) cannot occur until an initial intermolecular reaction occurs to generate the putative, acyclic oxocarbenium ion. Also of note, only one molecule of water is a byproduct of this cascade. The product molecules themselves represent a novel structural type, which is not present in nature. Thirty-two of these BiC molecules have been made, ten have been published, and at least twenty-two will be included in an extensive manuscript.

With this award, three students earned Master’s degrees in chemistry and twenty undergraduate coworkers also gained valuable research experience. The majority of undergraduate coworkers performed research in the P.I.’s laboratory for four or more semesters. Six former students are now in chemistry PhD programs: the University of Utah (two), Johns Hopkins, The Ohio State University, Auburn University and The University of Illinois. Another student obtained a M.S. at Princ...
